awd_titl_txt: A Comparative Study of the Mobilization and Mutation of Wildlife Management Strategies
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project will analyze how residents and officials in urban and suburban municipalities understand and respond to growing populations of white-tailed deer in their communities and how strategies for wildlife management spread among different locations.  This project will enhance fundamental knowledge about the ways that the interactions between humans and deer (as well as interactions with plants, ticks, and other objects involved in human-deer relationships) shape the motivations and rationales behind different wildlife management strategies.  The project will demonstrate how different management strategies circulate and evolve across different locations, with varied approaches to environmental management being adapted in different locales as humans and deer develop new relationships within cohabited spaces.  Through the examination of human-nonhuman relationships and the varied local and networked forces that influence the politics of wildlife management, this project will contribute new information and insights regarding wildlife management and environmental politics in urban and suburban environments.  Project findings will support the development of wildlife management strategies that are responsive to the distinct conditions of suburban and urban areas.  The project also will provide research-oriented education and training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students, and it will support the development of high school and college curricular materials that use suburban wildlife case studies to understand socioecological systems and environmental issues.

As many wildlife populations recover or migrate into urban and suburban residential areas, residents and local governments face new questions related to whether and how to manage species that previously were absent or rare.  Much of the research on wildlife management has been concerned with the maintenance of populations to support sustainable recreational hunting, herd health, and forest ecology, but wildlife management plans in suburban communities must respond to distinct concerns that often are related to health, safety, and property of people.  The successful population recovery and growth of many animal populations within suburban and urban environments raises questions about the place of animals in human-dominated spaces and challenges traditional wildlife management approaches.  The investigators will consider the shifting management strategies and policies related to white-tailed deer across municipalities in Massachusetts and New York, where deer populations have increased precipitously in many areas and many local governments have responded by creating hotly debated deer management programs that change access to public lands and hunting policies.  The investigators will seek answers to three sets of questions regarding emerging deer management strategies:  (1) How do concerns about deer and the practices of deer management differ across and within municipalities in Massachusetts and New York, and how have municipal rules about deer hunting changed over the past two decades?  (2) How have suburban managers (broadly defined to include all actors in deer management and conflicts) come to know and be concerned about deer, and when and how do deer become overabundant and thus an object of management?  (3) How have suburban managers learned about deer management, and how are management strategies from elsewhere negotiated and fit to new contexts?  The investigators will address these questions using a nested, mixed-method approach that will combines surveys, geospatial analysis, in-depth interviews, archival research, and participant observation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview and objectives: While urbanization and suburbanization are often thought of in relation to the loss of wildlife, many generalist species - such as geese, gulls, coyotes, deer - have been able to adapt and flourish in cities and suburbs. The growth of these generalist species in urban and suburban spaces can lead to concerns about their impacts on ecological and human health and prompt efforts to control their populations. Through a study of the management of white-tailed deer in Massachusetts (MA) and New York (NY), this project has examined the process and politics of creating and contesting wildlife management strategies in urban and suburban areas. Our objectives were (1) to understand how and why wildlife management decisions get made differently in different places, (2) to work with town officials and wildlife managers to support decision-making that reflects the diverse values and interests of suburban and urban residents, and (3) to create education and training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students.  

Research activities and findings: Our project had two stages. We first investigated the variation in local deer management strategies across our study area. We administered a survey to all municipalities in Massachusetts (MA) and New York (NY). The survey collected information about town-level concerns about local deer populations, local management practices, and information sharing across villages, towns, and cities.  

This portion of our research shows that suburban and urban towns and cities have become important actors in wildlife management. Even though state wildlife agencies have the legal responsibility for wildlife management, suburban and urban municipalities have become de facto wildlife managers through their ability to restrict and expand hunting access. We find that towns and cities exercise this power in different ways. Even in nearby towns with similar ecological and wildlife conditions, some cities and towns decide to actively manage deer while others do not.  

In the second portion of our research, we conducted in-depth case studies to investigate this variation. To study how and why some suburban towns decide to manage deer while others do not, we collected and analyzed over 200 deer management policies, related reports, and local media stories; we observed public meetings and viewed recordings of past meetings; and we conducted 34 interviews with town officials, state agency staff, residents, hunters, and other people involved in debates about deer management. 

Through this part of the project, we show how deer themselves (as well as other animals, plants, insects, and bacteria) are important actors in human politics and we unravel the multiple human interests that shape wildlife management. We find that municipal efforts to manage deer populations in suburban areas are linked to a mix of concerns about ecological health, human health and safety, and a desire to increase local hunting access. However, deer management programs don't simply emerge in response to broad public concern about these issues. Instead, our research shows that local deliberations about wildlife management are often catalyzed by a small number of politically active residents or town officials. Municipalities learn about deer management strategies from state agencies and neighboring communities but local politics and interests shape if and how controversies about management emerge and are negotiated.  

Our research draws attention to the ways the harm and care are entangled in the management of suburban and urban environments - deer are killed to protect forested ecosystems. Participants in debates about deer management hold diverging views on the ethics of lethal management as well as when humans should actively intervene in the environment. Yet, in many cases, the public debate centers on the availability and interpretation of data rather than the underlying interests and ethical perspectives of participants. Our research suggests that wildlife management may be enhanced by more directly acknowledging and engaging with the ethics and interests of those involved in debates.  

Contributions and impact: Our research and project activities forward scholarship on environmental controversies in urban and suburban areas and brings new insights to the study and practice of conservation and wildlife management. Throughout the project, we met with staff at wildlife agencies, town officials, conservation professionals, and residents to share data and discuss the implications of this research. To extend the reach of our work, we presented our research at conferences that bring together scholars and practitioners in geography, wildlife management, and conservation. 

Our project provided research opportunities, training, and educational experiences for undergraduate and graduate students. Fifteen students (including two PhD students, two MA students, and eleven undergraduates) gained research experience through this project. Their work resulted in one undergraduate capstone project and one doctoral dissertation. We actively engaged women and underrepresented minorities in the research (our research assistants include three students from underrepresented groups and 13 women). In addition, we have integrated data and insights from this project into undergraduate curricular materials in courses on human-environment relationships.
